SUMMARY:
Maltose inhibitor, MalI, is a repressor that controls genes related to maltose system. It is negatively autoregulated and coordinately represses transcription of a divergent operon that encodes a maltose-glucose PTS permease and a bifunctional protein that interacts directly with MalT transcriptional activator [2670898, 1856179].
This transcription factor binds to two 12-bp-long direct repeat nucleotide sequences in tandem, overlapping malXp and malIp simultaneously [2670898, 1856179].
MalI shows high similarity to GalR (28%), CytR (21%), and LacI (24%), and homology to a fragment of 30 amino acids from MalT. Additionally, N-terminal region has a helix-turn-helix DNA-binding domain [2670898]. gene encoding this protein is homologous to transcriptional repressors of LacI/GalR family.
